title: Islamic architecture
text:
Islamic architecture comprises the <a href="architectural%20style">architectural style</a>s of <a href="building">building</a>s associated with <a href="Islam">Islam</a>. It encompasses both <a href="Secularity">secular</a> and religious styles from the early <a href="history%20of%20Islam">history of Islam</a> to the present day. Islamic architecture developed to fulfill Islamic religious ideals, for example, the <a href="minaret">minaret</a> was designed to assist the <a href="muezzin">muezzin</a> in making his voice heard throughout a specific area.
Early Islamic architecture was influenced by <a href="Roman%20architecture">Roman</a>, <a href="Byzantine%20architecture">Byzantine</a>, <a href="Persian%20architecture">Persian</a>, <a href="Architecture%20of%20Mesopotamia">Mesopotamian</a> architecture and all other lands which the <a href="Early%20Muslim%20conquests">Early Muslim conquests</a> conquered in the seventh and eighth centuries. Further east, it was also influenced by <a href="Chinese%20architecture">Chinese</a> and <a href="Architecture%20of%20India">Indian architecture</a> as Islam spread to <a href="Southeast%20Asia">Southeast Asia</a>. Later it developed distinct characteristics in the form of buildings and in the <a href="Islamic%20ornament">decoration</a> of surfaces with <a href="Islamic%20calligraphy">Islamic calligraphy</a>, <a href="arabesque">arabesque</a>s, and <a href="Islamic%20geometric%20patterns">geometric motifs</a>. New architectural elements like <a href="minaret">minaret</a>s, "<a href="muqarnas">muqarnas</a>", and <a href="multifoil%20arch">multifoil arch</a>es were invented. Common or important types of buildings in Islamic architecture include <a href="mosque">mosque</a>s, <a href="madrasa">madrasa</a>s, <a href="tomb">tomb</a>s, <a href="palace">palace</a>s, <a href="hammam">hammam</a>s (public baths), <a href="Sufism">Sufi</a> <a href="Hospice">hospices</a> (e.g. <a href="khanqah">khanqah</a>s or <a href="Zawiya%20%28institution%29">zawiyas</a>), <a href="fountain">fountain</a>s and <a href="Sebil%20%28fountain%29">sabils</a>, commercial buildings (e.g. <a href="caravanserai">caravanserai</a>s and <a href="bazaar">bazaar</a>s), and military <a href="fortification">fortification</a>s.
Early history (up to 10th century).
The <a href="History%20of%20Islam">Islamic era</a> began with the formation of Islam under the leadership of <a href="Muhammad">Muhammad</a> in early 7th-century <a href="Arabian%20Peninsula">Arabia</a>. The first mosque was a structure built by Muhammad in <a href="Medina">Medina</a> in 622, right after his "<a href="hegira">hegira</a>" (migration) from <a href="Mecca">Mecca</a>, which corresponds to the site of the present-day <a href="Al-Masjid%20an-Nabawi">Mosque of the Prophet</a> ("al-Masjid an-Nabawi"). It is usually described as his house, but may have been designed to serve as a community center from the beginning. It consisted of a simple <a href="courtyard">courtyard</a> structure built in unbaked brick, with a rectangular, almost square, floor plan measuring about 53 by 56 meters. A shaded portico supported by palm trunks stood on the north side of the courtyard, in the direction of prayer (the "<a href="qibla">qibla</a>"), which was initially towards <a href="Jerusalem">Jerusalem</a>. When the "qibla" was changed to face towards Mecca in 624, a similar portico was added on the south side, facing towards that city. Muhammad and his family lived in separate rooms attached to the mosque, and Muhammad himself was buried in one of these rooms upon his death in 632. Over the rest of the 7th century and in the 8th century the mosque was repeatedly expanded to include a large flat-roofed prayer hall supported by columns (a hypostyle hall) with a central courtyard. It became one of the main models for the early mosques built elsewhere.
There are few other buildings dating from the era of Muhammad, but one example is the <a href="Jawatha%20Mosque">Jawatha Mosque</a> in <a href="Saudi%20Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>. During the early <a href="Early%20Muslim%20conquests">Arab-Muslim conquests</a> of the Middle East and North Africa in the 7th century, new garrison cities were established in territories such as <a href="Fustat">Fustat</a> in Egypt and <a href="Kufa">Kufa</a> in present-day Iraq. The central <a href="congregational%20mosque">congregational mosque</a>s of these cities were built in the <a href="hypostyle">hypostyle</a> format. In other cities, especially in <a href="Syria%20%28region%29">Syria</a>, new mosques were established by converting or occupying parts of existing churches in existing cities, as for example in <a href="Damascus">Damascus</a> and <a href="Hama">Hama</a>. These early mosques had no minaret, although small shelters may have been constructed on the roofs to protect the <a href="muezzin">muezzin</a> while issuing the <a href="Adhan">call to prayer</a>.
The <a href="Umayyad%20Caliphate">Umayyad Caliphate</a> (661–750) combined elements of pre-islamic <a href="Himyarite%20Kingdom">Himyarite</a>, <a href="Byzantine%20architecture">Byzantine architecture</a> and <a href="Sasanian%20architecture">Sasanian architecture</a>, but <a href="Umayyad%20architecture">Umayyad architecture</a> introduced new combinations of these styles with considerable <a href="Ghassanids">Ghassanid</a> influence. <a href="Ancient%20South%20Arabian%20art">South Arabian architecture</a> and styles of <a href="Ornament%20%28art%29">ornamentation</a> represent an immediate predecessor of the early Umayyads. The reuse of elements from <a href="Ancient%20Roman%20architecture">classical Roman</a> and <a href="Byzantine%20Empire">Byzantine</a> art was still widely evident because political power and patronage was centered in Syria, a former Roman/Byzantine province. However, a significant amount of experimentation occurred as Umayyad patrons recruited craftsmen from across the empire and architects were allowed, or even encouraged, to mix elements from different artistic traditions and to disregard traditional conventions and restraints. Partly as a result of this, Umayyad architecture is distinguished by the extent and variety of decoration, including <a href="Mosaic">mosaics</a>, wall painting, sculpture and carved reliefs. While figural scenes were notably present in monuments like <a href="Qusayr%20%27Amra">Qusayr 'Amra</a>, non-figural decoration and more abstract scenes became highly favoured, especially in religious architecture.
The <a href="horseshoe">horseshoe</a> arch appears for the first time in Umayyad architecture, later to evolve to its most advanced form in <a href="al-Andalus">al-Andalus</a> (<a href="Iberian%20Peninsula">Iberian Peninsula</a>). In hypostyle mosques, the Umayyads introduced the tradition of making the "nave" or aisle in front of the "mihrab" wider than the others, dividing the prayer room along its central axis. They also added the "<a href="mihrab">mihrab</a>" to mosque design, a concave niche in the "qibla" wall of the mosque. The first mihrab, a concave niche in the qibla wall, reportedly appeared at Muhammad's mosque in Medina when it was rebuilt by <a href="al-Walid%20I">al-Walid I</a> in 707. It seems to have represented the place where the Prophet stood when leading prayer. This almost immediately became a standard feature of all mosques. Several major early monuments of Islamic architecture built under the Umayyads include the <a href="Dome%20of%20the%20Rock">Dome of the Rock</a> in Jerusalem (built by Caliph <a href="Abd%20al-Malik%20ibn%20Marwan">Abd al-Malik</a>) and the <a href="Umayyad%20Mosque">Great Mosque of Damascus</a> (built by al-Walid I). The <a href="Al-Aqsa%20Mosque">Al-Aqsa Mosque</a> on the <a href="Temple%20Mount">Haram al-Sharif</a>, also in Jerusalem, was also rebuilt by al-Walid I, replacing an earlier simple structure built around 670. Both the al-Aqsa Mosque and the Great Mosque of Damascus featured a hypostyle hall and a <a href="dome">dome</a> above the space in front of the "mihrab", and both were influential in the design of later mosques elsewhere. A number of palaces from this period have also partially survived or have been excavated in modern times.
The <a href="Abbasid%20architecture">Abbasid architecture</a> of the <a href="Abbasid%20Caliphate">Abbasid Caliphate</a> (750–1513) was particularly influenced by <a href="Sasanian%20Empire">Sasanian</a> architecture, which in turn featured elements present since ancient <a href="Mesopotamia">Mesopotamia</a>. Other influences such as ancient <a href="Sogdia">Soghdian</a> architecture in Central Asia have also been noted. This was partly a result of the caliphate's political center shifting further east to the new capital of <a href="Baghdad">Baghdad</a>, in present-day Iraq. Abbasid mosques all followed the courtyard plan with hypostyle halls. The earliest was the mosque that Caliph <a href="al-Mansur">al-Mansur</a> built in Baghdad (since destroyed). The <a href="Great%20Mosque%20of%20Samarra">Great Mosque of Samarra</a> built by al-Mutawakkil was . A flat wooden roof was supported by columns. The mosque was decorated with marble panels and glass mosaics. The prayer hall of the <a href="Abu%20Dulaf%20Mosque">Abu Dulaf Mosque</a> at Samarra had arcades on rectangular brick piers running at right angles to the <a href="qibla">qibla</a> wall. Both of the Samarra mosques have spiral minarets, the only examples in Iraq. A mosque at <a href="Balkh">Balkh</a> in what is now Afghanistan was about square, with three rows of three square bays, supporting nine vaulted domes. While the origins of the minaret are uncertain, it is believed that the first true minarets appeared in this period. Several of the Abbasid mosques built in the early ninth century had minaret towers which stood at the northern ends of the building, opposite the central mihrab. Among the most famous of these is the Malwiyya minaret, a stand-alone tower with a "spiral" form built for the Great Mosque of Samarra.
After the overthrow of the Umayyad Caliphate in 750 by the Abbasids, a new branch of the <a href="Umayyad%20dynasty">Umayyad dynasty</a> succeeded in taking control of Al-Andalus in 756, creating the <a href="Emirate%20of%20C%C3%B3rdoba">Emirate of Cordoba</a> and reaching the apogee of its power during the <a href="Caliphate%20of%20C%C3%B3rdoba">Caliphate of Cordoba</a> in the 10th century. The <a href="Mezquita%20de%20C%C3%B3rdoba">Great Mosque at Córdoba</a>, built in 785–786, marks the earliest major monument of <a href="Moorish%20architecture">Moorish architecture</a> in the Iberian Peninsula (Al-Andalus). This style of architecture established in Al-Andalus was also largely shared with the architecture of western North Africa (the <a href="Maghreb">Maghreb</a>), from which later empires in the region would also emerge and contribute to its artistic evolution. The original Great Mosque of Cordoba was noted for its unique hypostyle hall with rows of double-tiered, two-coloured, arches, which were repeated and maintained in later extensions of the building. The mosque was expanded multiple times, with the expansion by <a href="al-Hakam%20II">al-Hakam II</a> (r. 961–976) introducing important aesthetic innovations such as interlacing arches and ribbed domes, which were imitated and elaborated in later monuments in the region. The construction of <a href="Madinat%20al-Zahra">Madinat al-Zahra</a>, a new capital and monumental palace-city in the 10th century, also created an important complex of royal architecture and patronage. Smaller monuments such as the early form of the <a href="University%20of%20al-Qarawiyyin">Qarawiyyin Mosque</a> in <a href="Fez%2C%20Morocco">Fez</a> (present-day <a href="Morocco">Morocco</a>) and the <a href="Mosque%20of%20Cristo%20de%20la%20Luz">Bab al-Mardum Mosque</a> in Toledo demonstrate the prevalence of the same stylistic elements across the region.
After its initial apogee of power, the Abbasid Caliphate became partly fragmented into regional states in the 9th century which were formally obedient to the caliphs in Baghdad but were "de facto" independent. The Aghlabids in <a href="Ifriqiya">Ifriqiya</a> (roughly modern-day <a href="Tunisia">Tunisia</a>) were notable patrons of architecture themselves, responsible for rebuilding both the <a href="Great%20Mosque%20of%20Kairouan">Great Mosque of Kairouan</a> (originally founded by <a href="Uqba%20ibn%20Nafi">Uqba ibn Nafi</a> in 670) and the <a href="Al-Zaytuna%20Mosque">Zaytuna Mosque</a> of <a href="Tunis">Tunis</a> in much of their current forms, as well as for building numerous other structures in the region. In Egypt, <a href="Ahmad%20ibn%20Tulun">Ahmad ibn Tulun</a> established a short-lived dynasty, the <a href="Tulunids">Tulunids</a>, and built himself a new capital (<a href="Al-Qata%27i">Al-Qata'i</a>) and a new congregational mosque, known as the <a href="Mosque%20of%20Ibn%20Tulun">Ibn Tulun Mosque</a>, which was completed in 879. It was strongly influenced by Abbasid architecture in <a href="Samarra">Samarra</a> and remains one of the most notable and best-preserved examples of 9th-century architecture from the Abbasid Caliphate.
In the 10th century the <a href="Fatimid%20Caliphate">Fatimid Caliphate</a> rose to power in Ifriqiya, where it built a new fortified capital at <a href="Mahdia">Mahdia</a>. In 970 the Fatimids moving their center of power to Egypt and they founded another new capital, <a href="Cairo">Cairo</a>. <a href="Fatimid%20architecture">Fatimid architecture</a> in Egypt followed Tulunid techniques and used similar materials, but also developed those of their own. Their first congregational mosque in Cairo was <a href="al-Azhar%20mosque">al-Azhar Mosque</a>, founded at the same time as the city (970), which became the spiritual center for the <a href="Ismaili">Ismaili Shi'a</a> branch of Islam. Other notable monuments include the large <a href="Al-Hakim%20Mosque">Mosque of al-Hakim</a> (founded in 990 under <a href="Al-Aziz%20Billah">al-'Aziz</a> but completed around 1013 under <a href="Al-Hakim%20bi-Amr%20Allah">al-Hakim</a>), the small <a href="Aqmar%20Mosque">Aqmar Mosque</a> (1125) with its richly-decorated street façade, and the domed <a href="Mashhad%20of%20Sayyida%20Ruqayya">Mashhad of Sayyida Ruqayya</a> (1133), notable for its "mihrab" of elaborately-carved <a href="stucco">stucco</a>. Under the powerful <a href="vizier">vizier</a> <a href="Badr%20al-Jamali">Badr al-Jamali</a> (r. 1073–1094), the city walls were rebuilt in stone along with several monumental gates, three of which have survived to the present-day: <a href="Bab%20al-Futuh">Bab al-Futuh</a>, <a href="Bab%20al-Nasr%20%28Cairo%29">Bab al-Nasr</a>, and <a href="Bab%20Zuweila">Bab Zuweila</a>).
Characteristics.
Some characteristics of Islamic architecture were inherited from pre-Islamic architecture of that region while some characteristics like <a href="minaret">minaret</a>s, "<a href="muqarnas">muqarnas</a>", <a href="arabesque">arabesque</a>, <a href="Islamic%20geometric%20patterns">Islamic geometric motifs</a>, <a href="Pointed%20arch%20%28architecture%29">pointed arch</a>, <a href="multifoil%20arch">multifoil arch</a>, <a href="onion%20dome">onion dome</a> and pointed dome developed later.
Gardens.
Gardens and water have for many centuries played an essential role in Islamic culture, and are often compared to the garden of <a href="Paradise">Paradise</a>. The comparison originates from the <a href="Achaemenid%20Empire">Achaemenid Empire</a>. In his dialogue "<a href="Oeconomicus">Oeconomicus</a>", <a href="Xenophon">Xenophon</a> has <a href="Socrates">Socrates</a> relate the story of the Spartan general <a href="Lysander">Lysander</a>'s visit to the <a href="Persian%20Empire">Persian</a> prince <a href="Cyrus%20the%20Younger">Cyrus the Younger</a>, who shows the Greek his "Paradise at Sardis". The classical form of the Persian <a href="Paradise%20garden">Paradise garden</a>, or the "<a href="charbagh">charbagh</a>", comprises a rectangular irrigated space with elevated pathways, which divide the garden into four sections of equal size:
One of the hallmarks of Persian gardens is the four-part garden laid out with axial paths that intersect at the garden's centre. This highly structured geometrical scheme, called the chahar bagh, became a powerful metaphor for the organization and domestication of the landscape, itself a symbol of political territory.
A Charbagh from Achaemenid time has been identified in the archaeological excavations at <a href="Pasargadae">Pasargadae</a>. The gardens of <a href="Chehel%20Sotoun">Chehel Sotoun</a> (<a href="Isfahan">Isfahan</a>), <a href="Fin%20Garden">Fin Garden</a> (<a href="Kashan">Kashan</a>), <a href="Eram%20Garden">Eram Garden</a> (<a href="Shiraz">Shiraz</a>), <a href="Shazdeh%20Garden">Shazdeh Garden</a> (<a href="Mahan%2C%20Iran">Mahan</a>), Dowlatabad Garden (<a href="Yazd">Yazd</a>), Abbasabad Garden (<a href="Abbasabad%2C%20Mazandaran">Abbasabad</a>), Akbarieh Garden (<a href="South%20Khorasan%20Province">South Khorasan Province</a>), <a href="Pahlevanpour%20Garden">Pahlevanpour Garden</a>, all in <a href="Iran">Iran</a>, form part of the <a href="World%20Heritage%20Site">UNESCO World Heritage</a>. Large Paradise gardens are also found at the <a href="Taj%20Mahal">Taj Mahal</a> (<a href="Agra">Agra</a>), and at <a href="Humayun%27s%20Tomb">Humayun's Tomb</a> (<a href="New%20Delhi">New Delhi</a>), in India; the <a href="Shalimar%20Gardens%20%28Lahore%29">Shalimar Gardens</a> (<a href="Lahore">Lahore</a>, <a href="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>) or at the <a href="Alhambra">Alhambra</a> and <a href="Generalife">Generalife</a> in <a href="Granada">Granada</a>, <a href="Spain">Spain</a>.
Courtyard ("Sahn").
In the architecture of the Muslim world <a href="courtyard">courtyard</a>s are found in secular and religious structures.
Hypostyle hall.
A <a href="hypostyle">hypostyle</a>, i.e., an open hall supported by columns, is considered to be derived from architectural traditions of <a href="Achaemenids">Achaemenid period</a> Persian assembly halls (<a href="apadana">apadana</a>). This type of building originated from the <a href="Roman%20architecture">Roman</a>-style <a href="basilica">basilica</a> with an adjacent courtyard surrounded by <a href="colonnade">colonnade</a>s, like <a href="Trajan%27s%20Forum">Trajan's Forum</a> in Rome. The Roman type of building has developed out of the <a href="Greek%20architecture">Greek</a> <a href="agora">agora</a>. In Islamic architecture, the hypostyle hall is the main feature of the hypostyle mosque. One of the earliest hypostyle mosques is the <a href="Tarikhaneh%20Temple">Tarikhaneh Mosque</a> in Iran, dating back to the eighth century.
Some scholars refer to the early hypostyle mosque with courtyard as the "Arab plan" or "Arab-type" mosque. Such mosques were constructed mostly under the Umayyad and Abbasid dynasties; subsequently, however, the simplicity of this type of plan limited the opportunities for further development, and as a result, these mosques gradually fell out of popularity in some regions.
Vaulting.
In Islamic buildings, <a href="Vault%20%28architecture%29">vaulting</a> follows two distinct architectural styles: While Umayyad architecture in the west continues Syrian traditions of the sixth and seventh century, eastern Islamic architecture was mainly influenced by Sasanian styles and forms.
Umayyad diaphragm arches and barrel vaults.
In their <a href="Vault%20%28architecture%29">vaulting</a> structures, Umayyad period buildings show a mixture of ancient Roman and Persian architectural traditions. <a href="Diaphragm%20arch">Diaphragm arch</a>es with lintelled ceilings made of wood or stone beams, or, alternatively, with barrel vaults, were known in the <a href="Levant">Levant</a> since the classical and <a href="Nabataeans">Nabatean</a> period. They were mainly used to cover houses and cisterns. The architectural form of covering diaphragm arches with barrel vaults, however, was likely newly introduced from <a href="Iranian%20architecture">Iranian architecture</a>, as similar vaulting was not known in <a href="Bilad%20al-Sham">Bilad al-Sham</a> before the arrival of the Umayyads. However, this form was well known in Iran from early <a href="Parthian%20Empire">Parthian</a> times, as exemplified in the Parthian buildings of <a href="Assur">Aššur</a>. The earliest known example for barrel vaults resting on diaphragm arches from Umayyad architecture is known from <a href="Qasr%20Al-Kharanah">Qasr Harane</a> in Syria. During the early period, the diaphragm arches are built from coarsely cut limestone slabs, without using supporting <a href="falsework">falsework</a>, which were connected by <a href="gypsum">gypsum</a> <a href="Mortar%20%28masonry%29">mortar</a>. Later-period vaults were erected using pre-formed lateral ribs modelled from gypsum, which served as a temporal formwork to guide and center the vault. These ribs, which were left in the structure afterwards, do not carry any load. The ribs were cast in advance on strips of cloth, the impression of which can still be seen in the ribs today. Similar structures are known from Sasanian architecture, for example from the palace of <a href="Firuzabad%2C%20Fars">Firuzabad</a>. Umayyad-period vaults of this type were found in <a href="Amman%20Citadel">Amman Citadel</a> and in <a href="Qasr%20Amra">Qasr Amra</a>.
Iwans.
The term <a href="iwan">iwan</a> denotes a hall that is walled on three sides and open on one side. It is typically covered by a vault although this can vary. This feature was present in Sasanian architecture, though its exact origins are older and still debated. It was later incorporated into Islamic architecture. Its usage became more common and widespread under the <a href="Seljuk%20Empire">Seljuks</a> in the 10th century. Iwans were used in a variety of ways and arranged in varying positions in relation to the rest of the building. They are found in many types of buildings including mosques, madrasas, palaces, and caravanserais. One characteristic layout consists of four iwans arranged around a central square or rectangular courtyard, with the iwans aligned with the central axes of the courtyard. For mosques and madrasas, one of the iwans could be oriented towards the "qibla" (direction of prayer) and include a "mihrab" in order to serve as a prayer space. The related <a href="Persian%20language">Persian</a> term, "pishtaq", is used to denote an entrance portal (sometimes an iwan) projecting from the façade of a building, often decorated with calligraphy bands, glazed tilework, and geometric designs.
Domes.
Domes in Iran and Central Asia.
Because of its long history of building and re-building, spanning the time from the <a href="Abbasids">Abbasids</a> to the <a href="Qajar%20dynasty">Qajar dynasty</a>, and its excellent state of conservation, the <a href="Jameh%20Mosque%20of%20Isfahan">Jameh Mosque of Isfahan</a> provides an overview over the experiments Islamic architects conducted with complicated vaulting structures.
The system of <a href="squinch">squinch</a>es, which is a construction filling in the upper angles of a square room so as to form a base to receive an <a href="octagon">octagon</a>al or <a href="sphere">spherical</a> dome, was already known in Sasanian architecture. The <a href="Spherical%20trigonometry">spherical triangles</a> of the squinches were split up into further subdivisions or systems of niches, resulting in a complex interplay of supporting structures forming an ornamental spatial pattern which hides the weight of the structure.
The tradition of double-shelled brick domes in Iran has been traced back to the 11th century. At the beginning of the 15th century, major Timurid monuments like the <a href="Gur-e-Amir">Gur-i Amir Mausoleum</a> and the <a href="Bibi-Khanym%20Mosque">Bibi Khanum Mosque</a> (both completed around 1404) were notable in their use of large double-shelled domes. These domes were composed of an inner shell which was visible from the interior and a larger outer shell, visible from the exterior and often of a slightly different shape. The Gur-i Amir Mausoleum's dome, the oldest one to have survived to the present day, features an exterior ribbed profile with a band of muqarnas around its drum. However, domes of this shape and style were likely constructed earlier, as evidenced by the <a href="Sultaniyya%20Mausoleum">Sultaniyya Mausoleum</a> in Cairo, which was built earlier in the 1350s and appears to have copied this same design from the Iranian tradition.
The "non-radial rib vault", an architectural form of ribbed vaults with a superimposed spherical dome, is the characteristic architectural vault form of the Islamic East. From its beginnings in the Jameh Mosque of Isfahan, this form of vault was used in a sequence of important buildings up to the period of <a href="Safavid%20dynasty">Safavid</a> architecture.
